Hill. --He says that, having heard of what a pions man the General was, and belonging to the same church with him, he expected to be treated with some consideration by that officer; but that, upon asking sundry favors, he found that his ecclesiastical relation was of little service, and that he is inclined to think that the General has a small opinion even of a preacher who comes to aid in subduing the South.

div3.head: The army of the West.
div3.p:
--Gen. Bragg has issued a general order assuming the command of the Army of the West, as successor to Gen. Beauregard who has been relieved.
He concludes as follows.

p.q: "A few more days of needful preparation and organization and I shall give our banners to the breeze — shall lead you to emulate the soldiers of the Confederacy in the East, and with the confident trust you will gain additional honors to those you have already won on other fields; but be prepared to undergo privation and labor with cheerfulness and alacrity."

div3.head: Suppressing a Pater.
div3.p:
--The Memphis Avalanche having published an incendiary and treasonable article headed Mischief makers," on the 1st of July General Great ordered that paper to be suspected.
The otherwise subsequently countermanded on the withdrawn of the editor who wrote the article from the Avalanche establishment.
The Common Council of Buffalo, N. Y., has appropriated $80,000 to raise a new regiment, giving are bounty to each fearful, is addition to the Government bounty.

div3.head: From the Southwest.
div3.p:
--Memphis papers, of the 9th, state that Andy Johnson was daily expected in that city.
The Union Appeal, of Memphis, (Grant's organ,) says that Butler has confiscated 3,000 slaves and put them to work upon the canal opposite Vicksburg.
The New York Post fears that conscription or drafting will have to be resorted to if Lincoln's 3000,000 men are to be raised.

Black Republican dispatches claim a victory in Tuesday's battle, and say that McClellan has since removed his headquarters five miles nearer Richmond.
Our forces are represented by them as retiring to their old position.

Gen. Chaimer's brigade of cavalry at Ripley, last Monday.
attacked and dispersed the Yankees assembled at that point.

Jackson, July 10.--General Van Dorn has issued a General Order No, 9, which places fifteen counties contiguous to Vicksburg and all of East Louisiana under martial law. It is declared that disloyalty will not be countenanced; the credit of the Government must be sustained; the seeds of discontent are not to be sown among the troops; speculators will not be tolerated, but be arrested and fined; newspapers will not publish the movements of troops under the penalty of suspension, fine and imprisonment.
Passengers from Memphis say that Hindman has captured Curtis, and that the news was believed in Memphis.

Mobile,July 12.--A special dispatch to the Advertiser, dated Jackson, 11th, states that the enemy were vigorously employed in shelling Vicksburg, effecting but little damage.
The Yankees are pillaging the plantations on the river of horses mules, and everything else valuable.
Negroes are impressed to work upon the canal across the river bend.

div3.head: How the Yankees lie.
div3.p: --The Tribune, of this city, has received a copy of the New Orleans Delta, of the 10th instant, containing the following "glorious news."

Great battle fought!
Richmond fallen!! Fifty thousand rebel prisoners taken!!! The last ditch captured!!!! The Tennessee has arrived from below Vicksburg, bringing the following important intelligence; "On the 6th instant General Halleck sent a dispatch to Commodore Davis, commanding the American fleet above announcing that he had just received a telegram from General Grant, stating that a great battle had been fought at Richmond, with immense loss of life on both sides.
Richmond had been captured after a desperate struggle, and fifty thousand Confederates taken prisoners with a vast quantity of stores, ammunition, guns, etc.

We have no reason to doubt the authenticity of this great news as it comes through a semi official channel of a most reliable character.
Three cheers for McClellan and the army of the Union!"

div4.p: On Sunday morning, the 13th instant, at 6½ o'clock, Mildred Louisa New, aged 14 years 8 months and 19 days, oldest daughter of James W. and Louisa New.

The subject of the above notice was a young and blooming flower, just budding forth into beautiful womanhood.
She had just reached that age when fond and loving parents and relatives had formed large expectations of future usefulness, and her rapid acquirement of all the accomplishments of society, gave promise of great proficiency.
As a child she was remarkable for a cheerful and loving obedience in all things to her parents, and her ardent attachment to her sent and other relatives, gave evidence of a warm and devoted heart, by which she was endeared to them all. As a Sunday school scholar she was regular in attendance, earnest and attentive in her studies, and an ornament to this sacred institution.
Though so young, and so suddenly taken away from us by the dispensation of God, we have abundant reason to cherish the hope that she is now among the angels of Heaven; for, while living, she exemplified the Christian character, and in her death was permitted to testify that trusting in Christ she had found salvation.
Farewell, thoued of promise, we shall meet thee again in the world of bliss.
A Friend.

The funeral will take place from Trinity Church, corner Broad and 20th streets, on this (Monday) evening, at 5½ o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
On Sunday evening 13th inst., Virginia Evans, youngest child of C. K. and Virginia Chapin, aged 15 months.
The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral this (Monday) evening, from her father's residence, second door from the corner of Leigh, on 9th street, at 5 o'clock.

On the 13th inst., of diphtheria, Marcelena Waring, daughter of Jno.
B. and Mary F. Vaughan, aged five years ten months and thirteen days.

lg.l: "When those we love are snatched away,
Our hearts the mournful tribute pay
Oh, let us to that Saviour fly.
Then shall our hopes ascend on high,

div4.p: The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully requested to attend her funeral, from her father's residence, No. 33, Main street, this afternoon, the 14th inst., at 5 o'clock P. M.

In Danville, on Saturday, June 28th, 1862. of typhoid pneumonia, at his grand-fathers', Mr. George Price, George W. Law.
aged 19 years and 2 days. He was a member of the "Danville Blues," Company A, Capt. J. A. Holland, 18th Regiment Virginia Volunteers.

Thus died a faithful soldier, and a true defender of the rights of the South, after having been engaged in several desperate battles, and being mercifully preserved, God saw fit to take him away by disease.
Dear. Willie was a brave boy, and was among the first to respond to the call of his country.
On Wednesday, July 9th, quarter after 3 o'clock, Julian Alexander, the infant son of Peter and Mary G. Farce, aged two months and six days.

lg.l: His little crib is empty now,
A mother's hope, a mother's Joy,
In death's cold arms doth lie.
Weep not for me, my mother dear,
I have gone to rest, you need not fear.
My stay was short, as you may see,
Therefore prepare to follow me. M.

div4.p: At the residence, of Mr. Wm. Holt Richardson, in this city, on the 11th inst., Dr. Wm. Thos. Eley, Lieut. Co. C, 6th Reg't Va. Vols.

Amongst the many brave sons of the South who have yielded up their lives in resisting a cruel war waged upon us by our desperate foe, no one has approached danger more unflinching, nor have any borne the agonies of a fatal wound with less complaint than has Lieut Eley.
But human efforts were unavailing, and patient suffering could not avert the soy the of the inevitable reaper in his life, Lieut. Eley was beloved by all with whom he came in contact, and in his dying moments he showed how a brave and gallant soldier can meet the fate of war without murmur, when strengthened with the consciousness of duty well performed.
At the residence of Mr. Wm. Greanor, on Friday, June 20th. of wounds received in the battle of Seven Pines, Charles P. Clark, of 2d Florida Regiment, in the 21st year of his age.
Farewell, Charlie; in another and better world we shall meet, where the sorrow and ills of this life will be but a shadow. M. C.
Mobile and Greeneville (Ala) papers please copy.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, suddenly, on the battle filed on the evening of the 27th June, Lieut. D. M. Keeler, in the 23d year of his age.

The fatal bullet reached his heart, and without a struggle this brave young officer and soldier died, but not until he had struggled many times with the enemy in the defence of his country.
Young healthy, and brave, he constituted one of the firm rocks of the old Stonewall.
As an officer of Company C. 2d Virginia regiment, he was much beloved.
As a soldier we need but look back to Manassas, to Kernstown, Winchester, Port Republic, and then at Richmond, to see that he was all his country could asked but thy race is run, noble soldier.
Sleep on in peace, fond parents and kind friends can but mourn thy loss, while a grateful county will ever cherish thy name.
J. W. H., Co. C, 2d Va. Reg.
Staunton papers copy.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p:
--My negro boy John, 12 years old, absented himself about two weeks ago, When last heard from he was at one of the neighboring camps.
He has large eyes, quite shrewd, and is apt to misrepresent as to his owner, name, &c. I will pay a suitable reward for his return.
Chas. E. Whitlock.
jy 14--6t* Broad, between 23d and 24th sts.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on the night of the 7th inst., a negro boy named MacKENZIEenzie.
He is 22 years of age, low, heavy set, with bad looking eyes.
Said boy was brought from Essex county, six months ago. I will pay the above reward, if delivered to me in Richmond.
Theodore Frick,
jy 14--3t* Upper Market.

div3.head: Catch the Deserter.
div3.p: --John J. Peterson, deserted from my company (attached to DeGournay's Battalion on or about the 8th inst.--He is supposed to be lurking around Richmond, or at his home at Weldon, N. C. The usual Government reward will be paid for his apprehension to me at Redoubt No. 4, near this city.
div3.closer:
Capt. J. Hatley Norton.
jy 14--1t* Commanding Post.

div3.head: Notice to Commandants of Companies.
div3.p: --Commandants of Companies who desire, to have their companies mustered into service or for pay, will find me at the office of Gen. Winder, during office hours.
div3.closer:
Samuel T. Bayly, Capt. P. A. C. S.,
jy 14--6t* A. A. Gen'l and Mustering Officer.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--All members of the Charles City troop absent from any cause, are hereby ordered to report to this company at the camp of the 3rd Va. Cavalry.
All orderlies are relieved except those with Gen. Lee.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Wm. F. Goode. F. Guy.
jy 14--3t* Captain Commanding Company.

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
--John W. Ducas, a member of my company.
Said Lucas is about 25 years of age, stout built, about 5 feet 10 inches high, light hair, blue eyes.
He lives in Hanover county, near what is known as the Yellow Tavern.
The reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me or to any prison in this city.
div3.closer:
L. J. Hawley.
Capt. Co. D, 10th Reg't Cavalry, Stuart's Brig. E.
jy 14--4t*

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
--Henry M. Wicks, a member of my company.
Said Wicks is about 23 years of age, dark hair, black eyes, genteel locking about 5 feet 9 inches high, stout built, and reported himself to be from Texas.
The usual reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me or to any prison in this city.
div3.closer:
L. J. Hawley, Capt Co. D.
jy 14--4t* 10th Reg't Va. Cav'y, Stuart's Brig.

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
--Marquis Haves a member of my company.
Said Hayes is about 26 years of age, 5 feet 10 inches high, well proportioned, black hair, grey eyes, rather quick spoken, and represented himself to be from Tennessee.--The reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me, or to any of the prisons in this city.
div3.closer:
L. J. Hawley, Capt. Co., D.
jy 14--4t* 10th Reg't Va. Cav'y Stuart's Brig.

div3.p:
--Deserted from Col. J. Luclus Davis's camp, on the night of the 7th inst., C. C. Clark a has C. Reny, while under arrest for various charges.
Said Clark is about 20 years of age, about 5 feet 8 inches high, light hair, blue eyes.--The reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me.
div3.closer:
L. J. Hawley.
jy 14--4t* Capt. Co. D. 10th Reg't Cav.
